Can this be considered a Flight Regularity Message??

options.text: No, because individual requirements of passengers or crew shall NOT be admissible in this type of message.
No, because this type of message can only be passed once the aircraft is on the ground and passed onto the DELIVERY controller.
Yes, provided the ATSU has responsibility for ground handling services at the planned destination aerodrome.
Yes, because this is information for a representative of the aircraft`s operating agency and may be relayed by the ATSU.

DxMHNEFu.question: What is the meaning of APV?

options.text: “””Approach procedure with vertical guidance””: an instrument procedure which utilises lateral and vertical guidance but does not meet the requirements established for precision approach and landing operations.”
“””Approach performed only in VMC””: the restriction of an approved procedure to land at an aerodrome only when the aerodrome`s ATS unit reports VFR meteorological conditions.”

“””Aerodrome probable visibility””: the visibility used in case of failure of visibility-measuring instruments at an aerodrome, based on estimates by a human observer with knowledge of the aerodrome environment.”

“””Aerodrome proximity visualisation””: an augmented-reality visualisation through any computer-based system of the essential elements at or in the close vicinity of an aerodrome, such as obstacles and signs.”

lWVMoGBq.question: What is the meaning of APV?

options.text: “Approach procedure with vertical guidance”: an instrument procedure which utilises lateral and vertical guidance but does not meet the requirements established for precision approach and landing operations.

“Aerodrome probable visibility”: the visibility used in case of failure of visibility-measuring instruments at an aerodrome, based on estimates by a human observer with knowledge of the aerodrome environment.

“Aerodrome proximity visualisation”: an augmented-reality visualisation through any computer-based system of the essential elements at or in the close vicinity of an aerodrome, such as obstacles and signs.
“Approach performed only in VMC”: the restriction of an approved procedure to land at an aerodrome only when the aerodrome`s ATS unit reports VFR meteorological conditions.”

Direction finding message, distress message, urgency message.

No, because this type of message can only be passed once the aircraft is on the ground and passed onto the DELIVERY controller.

jrgROVds.question: What is the definition of an Instrument Approach procedure?

options.text: A series of predetermined manoeuvres by reference to flight instruments with specified protection from obstacles from the initial approach fix, or where applicable, from the beginning of a defined arrival route to a point from which a landing can be completed and thereafter, if a landing is not completed, to a position at which holding or en-route obstacle clearance criteria apply.

A straight in approach by reference to flight instruments from the initial approach fix, or where applicable, from the beginning of a defined arrival route to a point from which a landing can be completed and thereafter, if a landing is not completed, to a position at which holding or en-route obstacle clearance criteria apply.

A series of predetermined manoeuvres by reference to flight instruments with specified protection from obstacles from the intermediate approach fix, or where applicable, from the beginning of a defined arrival route to a point from which a landing can be completed and thereafter, if a landing is not completed, to a position at which holding or en-route obstacle clearance criteria apply.
A defined manoeuvre by reference to the FMS and HUD from the initial approach fix, or at the beginning of a defined arrival route to a point from which a landing can be completed.

hC41vSx3.question: ATC clearance for taxi issued by a controller will always contain a clearance limit. This is the point at which the aircraft must stop, unless further permission to proceed is given. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this type of clearance?

options.text: When a taxi instruction contains a taxi limit beyond a runway, it shall contain an explicit clearance to cross, or an instruction to hold short of that runway.
Taxi instructions never contain a clearance to cross a runway, even if the clearance limit is beyond that runway.
The controller would never issue taxi instructions where these would take the aircraft to a clearance limit which would involve crossing a runway.
In the case the taxi instruction requires the crossing of a runway, the clearance limit will explicitly be to hold short of that runway.

QLJ39g9r.question:
ATC clearance for taxi issued by a controller will always contain a clearance limit. This is the point at which the aircraft must stop, unless further permission to proceed is given. 

Which of the following statements is correct regarding this type of clearance?

options.text: When a taxi instruction contains a taxi limit beyond a runway, it shall contain an explicit clearance to cross, or an instruction to hold short of that runway.
In the case the taxi instruction requires the crossing of a runway, the clearance limit will explicitly be to hold short of that runway.
Taxi instructions never contain a clearance to cross a runway, even if the clearance limit is beyond that runway.
The controller would never issue taxi instructions where these would take the aircraft to a clearance limit which would involve crossing a runway.

d3juTSXE.question: What is the definition of CAVOK?

options.text: Visibility is 10km or more, no significant cloud below 5000ft, no significant weather.
Visibility is 5km or more, no significant cloud below 5000ft, no significant weather.
Visibility is 10km or more, no significant cloud below 10,000ft, no significant weather.
Visibility is 5km or more, no significant cloud below 10,000ft, no significant weather.

M0PQtS3p.question: What is the definition of CAVOK?

options.text: Visibility is 10 000 m or more, no significant cloud below 1500 m, no significant weather.
Visibility is 5000 m or more, no significant cloud below 1500 m, no significant weather.
Visibility is 10 000 m or more, no significant cloud below 5000 m, no significant weather.
Visibility is 5000 m or more, no significant cloud below 10,000 m, no significant weather.
